markdown.content:
Old Art & Thoughts

This chost is better in light mode.

A lot of artists are ashamed of exposing their old art (understandable) and I share this sentiment in part. But, by not showing this aspect of our history, a lot of growth, determination and passion that could really help starting artists -and even help us understand who we are and was- is being wasted on an old dusty folder.

In this chost I want to highlight some old art of mine, comment and tell a little bit of my trajectory. (Also, I'll be using DAY/MONTH/YEAR format, get used to it. And you might also notice a discrepancy between the date on the image and the date on the label: the label states when I started, the signature states when I finished).

*cahem*

The voicesvoices are telling me I'm not good enough to have a "trajectory chost". But you shouldn't put yourself down, so I won't put myself down either, deal?

2020

I always wanted to get into digital art. But while I didn't have a tablet, I decided to try pixel art, since I could do it with a mouse. My main reference at that point was Brandon James Greer. When I started watching his videos, he often drew 2D backgrounds, and so those became my main subject during my pixel art phase.

13/04/20

I first started making pixel art in gimpgimp. I don't want to talk about it, please don't make me talk about it.

Anyway, you can see that the pixels are sized irregularly and are desaligned in some spots. But besides that, I think it's still a cute piece for a beginner! One motif that is pretty noticeable throughout this phase, are plants. Especially hanging plants.

•︎

After 3 pixel arts in gimp, I finally bought Aseprite.

14/05/20

To this day I still like this one. The colors are nice, there's a nice variety of plants and the whole setup works.

I want to live in a big city someday. People complain a lot about big cities, and with reason. Air polution, high prices, too many cars, etc. But I hope I can overcome all that in the future. I've always lived in a small suburban city. And, although I have emotional attachment to here, the lack of motion and activity suffocates me.

Anyway, one thing I really like in 2d pixel art is when the foreground works as a border, but still contains elements of the background. Brandon do this a lot, and so did I.

•︎

02/10/20

This one is supposed to be "the other side" of the previous art. It is a mess regarding color and composition, but I still have some attachment to it.

I used that art as a banner when I started streaming. I streamed for some time during the first year of the pandemic. But then I got busy with school and, at the moment, my last stream was in 2021.

Even if it didn't last long, I had a lot of fun and great moments streaming! Most of my chatters were close online friends of mine, which made it even more special. I'll always remember those days fondly. :eggbug:

That being said, Sonic 2 sucks and it would be really cool if Twitch gave me those 30 dollars that are stuck in my account...

•︎

25/10/20

On October 22nd, my birthday, I finally got my Wacom One. After playing with it for a while and learning KritaKrita, I finally exported my first digital drawing.

Being honest, there's nothing much special about it, just me trying to recall some anime tutorials I had watched years ago. But I wanted to point the start of my digital eradigital era anyway.

•︎

04/12/20

I'm not imune to Dunning-Kruger Effect, so I drew a lot in my first ~2 months of digital art. And I drew fast.

Overall, all of my drawigs were pretty basic and amateurish. I don't recall putting too much effort into each one of them individually, but this "first" Saulo design was one of the first time I actually drew with references. And so it is one of the best from that year.

Oh yeah, I was also trying to make lineart with a pressure sensitive brush while using a pretty heavy stabilizer, so my line weight definitely wasn't the best.

•︎

29/12/20

The anatomy is not great, the perspective is a little bit weird, the composition could be more well thought, and the colors are too much flat and dessaturated. Still, I appreciate a lot the effort and that I had the balls to try composing a full-ass scene with perspective involved.

Learning and trying new abilities is something that requires a lot of courage and passion. And putting those abilities to the test for the first time is even harder. Obviously, the first result won't reflect your full potencial, and that's something I have to constantly keep reminding myself of...

2021

During my first years of digital art, I was really into flat colors and cell-shading. Picking colors and shading with multiply was pretty fun and convenient, until I let perfeccionism take control. Suddenly, I started using the same colors to shade, always making the same "block of color" background and even using the same brush size for all my lineart. That phase didn't last too much, but still was something way out of my radar that got me completely off guard.

•︎

14/02/21

Fast forward a little bit and we are getting into my REALLY COLORFUL PHASEREALLY COLORFUL PHASE. I was really inspired by Hades art style, especially the colorful highlights in the character's 2D sprites. And because I didn't had much color theory in mind, I just put really saturated color whenever I could and hope for the best. It was interesting, at least.

I remember having a lot of fun during those months. It was a healthy balance of trying to get better, but also being satisfied with my results. Also, splashing colors everywhere is just inherently fun. So much that I still do that to this day, but in more subtle ways. :eggbug:

•︎

22/05/21

Since the beginning I have always shared my art with friends. And having really talented friends that are evolving along side me is something that inspires me a lot. Sometimes I like to dig some old art [NAME DROP!] of them to see how much they improved, but don't tell them that!!! :eggbug:

This is Said's OC, who is a really talented friend of mine. He was a big reference for my style in the beginning.

Multiple art tutorials recommends developing your own style by borrowing elements of other artists styles. And, although this is a good tip and something I do a lot, I have this really bad habit of electing a "correct style". Basically when I see a style I like my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "oh wow, I should draw exactly like that". But then I see another style I like and my brain goes "Why are you inspecting my chost? Weirdo".

•︎

14/12/21

On the last quarter of 2021, I decided I wanted a more organic and loose style. I wasn't going to abandon cell-shading [yet], but I wanted something less "perfect". I admire a lot artists that convey life and emotion through more organic and abstract shapes, textures, colors and paint strokes.

I actively look after "flaws" in other people artwork: sketch lines that weren't erased, colors going beyond the blocks they belong, shadings that weren't as well blended than others, background elements that were draw more roughtly than the rest, etc. All that are human marks, it extends the artwork to a more personal level. I'm not looking at an image, I'm looking at an image that someone made.

Unfortunately, that's something I struggle a lot until this day. The things I most appreciate, suddenly become an incompetence on my part. Of course, that's another symptom of perfeccionism, and I'm trying my best to get over it!

This pokemon card was part of an art trade I made with some friends, the artist I drew being Amaya_Kirisu. It was really fun trying to come up with a card that matches her personality! It is a great change of pace that I recommend a lot!!

Anyway, I was really into Skullgirls at the time, and I was trying to mimic at some extend the style of it's sprites. Specially the shading.

2022

For a long time (2 years), I tried to make a cool portrait of myself to use as profile picture on social media. And every time I tried, it just didn't feel right. Not in a profound way, it just didn't look like myself. And it seemed like the more I tried to make it look like me, the less it ended up looking like me.

28/02/22

Then I decided to go in the opposite way. And it fucking worked???

I often think a lot about abstract art and the concept of symbols. In short terms and based on my own opinion and thoughts, artists utilizes symbols (relatively realistic representations of real objects and concepts) to guide the feelings and interpretations of the viewer when experiencing their art. The more abstract these symbols are, the less guided the viewer is. Based on that, when I stopped trying to represent myself realistic, the key elements of my appearance were able to really stand out. And thus, look like myself.

This painting is also really important to the timeline. From that, I started developing my own brush, which I used a lot.

•︎

28/07/22

After a long period of time without finishing a piece, I finally went on vacation from school. And then, discovered Art Fight. I never had participated in something like Art Fight before, and it was such a great experience! The whole atmosphere of the event really puts me in the mood of spending 5~6 hours drawing per day. It was also a great opportunity to pick up the pace and develop my style and skills.

The thing is, I only discovered Art Fight 2 weeks before the event ended. And you may be thinking "Oh well, what a shame. Working on a reduced deadline is not great at all", but you don't know me. When I'm running out of time, and all the odds are against me, that's when I shine. Out of pure spite and anger, I become ecstatic, furious. My soul is burning in determination like never before. And thus, I give my best: my whole and true potencial is unleashed in a last leap of faith...

Of course this backfires occasionally, but I'm fine with the consequences. :eggbug:

Character belongs to Ddes.

•︎

28/07/22

As you get better in your area, suddenly you start observing things you thought was way out of your scope and think "maybe I can do that".

I was listening to one of those 24/7 lo-fi radio livestreams when I looked at the background animation and decided I wanted to make that. Of course I don't have the ability and knowledge to make one of those beatiful and well-thought backgrounds animations even today. But I wanted to try making something simpler but similar just for fun. :eggbug:

An apartment kitchen at night with a view of a rainy city and a cat??? That's, like, the biggest combo of self interests I've ever done. :O

Regarding the process, I struggled a lot with lighting and also learning how to animate. But, overall, it was a really fun and enjoyable! I even edited it into a video with music and white noise, and uploaded it on youtube.

•︎

25/12/22

Initially I wouldn't include this one. But art isn't always rainbows and roses, so I think it's fair to write about it.

I hate it. But before explaining why, here's some context: in december of 2022, Artfol was hosting a Christmas event. I had already made 4 out of the 5 artworks required to complete the event, and so I wanted to make the final one a little more complex than the others. And, to be clear, there's absolutely nothing wrong with being ambicious and trying new things, that's actually really great and important! But I made a series of bad decisions that made this artwork's process absolutely horrible:

  1. I had less than a week left to make one of the most complex pieces I had done until that day.
  2. I spent too much time trying to fix a sketch I didn't even like.
  3. I could take a step back and make something easier. But I didn't because "I had already put too much effort and time on it".
  4. I decided to proceed with an unfinished sketch [that I didn't even like] hoping that I would fix it later.
  5. I spent the whole afternoon of Christmas Eve finishing it when I should be sleeping instead.

I really tried to see the positive side of things and minimally like it. But I can't help but hate it. At least I hope I can learn from my mistakes.

2023

Well, Christmas incident wasn't able to stop me, because January of 2023 was full of artworks even more complex than those from December.

25/01/23

After the announcement of Rift of The Necrodancer, I was really interested in the animation style of the characters. I can't tell exactly if it is rigging or not, but it's similar. I was still in the hype for animation, and so I started searching about rigging in 2d animation.

Krita's animation curves tool is not rigging, but it can function like it. It basically can get properties from a layer's mask and change it according to a timeline. And, if you create a hierarchical structure with your layers, you can combine movements while they are independent still. Of course that's still way more limited than actual rigging, but you can make some really cool stuff with it!!

Krita's animation curves is a relatively new feature and it's still pretty unpolished. Even though it's a simple animation, it was so hard to make things work while my PC was freezing all the time... I can't believe I actually finished it in one day.

(I realized just now that the lamb's shadow should get bigger when they're away from the ground, not the contrary... Oh well...)

•︎

27/01/23

I always hated making lineart. At the beggining, all my lines were made in one shot with a really strong stabilizer, wich required a lot of attempts. Then, I switched my main brush to a textured one, wich helped masking imperfections a little. But erasing and connecting lines to make them fluid was still a pain in the ass. Besides perfeccionism, the process wasn't enjoyable for me at all in the first place.

I didn't intend to give up on lineart completely. Even though it was awful to make, I still liked the way it looked. And thus, I slowly tried to minimize the places where I used lineart, generally reserving it to stablish borders and blocks of color.

My anatomy and rendering skill weren't very good yet, so the volumes are not so well defined. Also I didn't have a good grasp on values, so all my shadows were pretty weak for a long time.

There's this funny thing that happens from time to time, in which two contexts becomes irreversibly connected in my memory. Let me explain: when my mind stays focused in two things at the same time for a long period of time, these two things reminds me of the other everytime I recall one of them. It can be a song and a place, a movie and a food, a book and a period of time, a game and a feeling, etc etc. In this case, everytime I see this artwork, I immediately recall the livestream I was watching while painting the background.

I wonder if that's actually a common phenomenon, but I've never seen anyone talk about it.

•︎

07/02/23

This artwork is from a challenge hosted on Artfol in which you have two draw the same subject in an old style and in your current one. I don't have a lot to say about it, but I wanted to include it here because it was a really interesting experience analyzing old art [NAME DROP AGAIN!] to recreate it after so much have changed. It kinda makes you compare who you are today with who you were.

•︎

05/04/23

I was not in the mood for lining when I started finishing this piece, so I decided to paint first, and then line it. But throughout the process, an innocent and simple thought crossed my mind. "What if I don't line this at all?". Ladies, gentlemen and non-binary, as simple as it is, this was the most important leap of faith that got me where I am today.

After I realized that I could just skip the step I most hated, a new range of possibilities appeared right in front of my eyes. I finally decided that beyond everything, I wanted to paint. And I wanted to get better at it.

•︎

21/07/23

It's July, month that I joined Cohost! \o/

Coincidentally, I received some Michel Lauricella's anatomy books as a gift from a relative, and after it bought Guilherme Freitas' Fundamentals of Digital Illustration course. My sketchbook was finally completed, full of anatomical drawings. I was studying anatomy, render, colors, composition, perspective, all at the same time. I was on fire.

One thing that I can now confidently say is, if you really wants to improve your art skills and you can afford it, invest in books, courses and tutoring from good authors. Of course you can taught yourself with free resources and self observations, but didatic material really makes a difference. (Just don't forget to also have fun making art, especially if you have just started).

•︎

24/07/23

It's also Art Fight month!

One of the most popular method used by industry professionals is to make a grayscale only painting, and then using blending modes to paint over it. I really tried this approach multiple times, but it never ended how I wanted. After a while, I discovered Krita's Gradient Maps, how they work is basically applying a color gradient following the grayscale gradient values.

The biggest struggle is mapping the colors in the gradient, but once you get the hang of it, it's pretty handy! In fact, the last two artworks you saw were colored using gradient maps. Except... I stopped using them after 3 drawings. Don't get me wrong, they were really useful in my proces when I used them. But my favorite part of the process is coloring, and coloring through mapping is not fun at all...

Characters belongs to @navomeister.

•︎

After that last one, all my new artwork is being documented here, on Cohost. Go see it! :eggbug:

Extras

Here are some other artworks that I would like to include but didn't fit well in the text. Feel free to skip this part.

22/05/20

05/06/20

03/03/21

20/06/21

05/03/22

13/08/22

16/12/22

23/03/23

20/02/23

Conclusion

One of the greatest irony of human nature is the natural desire to be infinite while being a finite being.

You've probably heard variants of "you'll never be fully satisfied with your art", and that's true. It's natural to want to improve, to make something better, to make something bigger. And, for that, it's inherently necessary that we are never satisfied. The lack of an ending doesn't implies a meaningless journey, but that there'll always be a new and exciting next step to take.

So why rush it? Take your time. Don't try to be perfect. Take a step back when necessary. Eventually you'll achieve what you want. If our journey doesn't have an ending, the best we can do is enjoy the ride. :eggbug:

Hey! Thanks a lot for reading!!!


Wow, this ended up being way much bigger than I first intended... I not very good at writing, but I put a lot of effort in this chost. So I hope I entertained you at least.

Also thanks to @navomeister for proofreading this whole thing!


See you soon,

-NekoRaita
